floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
This is a message from the Environment Agency. 

Flood Alert no longer in force: Tyne estuary. 

The situation has improved and no further flooding is expected in this area.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to expected rainfall throughout the morning, 27/8/24.  A band of heavy rain is expected to cross Cumbria throughout the morning, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area. This will be followed by a period of showers, clearing by this evening.  Lake levels are currently falling but are expected to rise again from lunchtime today. It is expected that this Flood Alert will remain in force until at least the middle of the week. Rivers in the area may also show some response and start rising from mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any further flood warnings.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to expected rainfall throughout the morning, 27/8/24.  A band of heavy rain is expected to cross Cumbria throughout the morning, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area. This will be followed by a period of showers, clearing by this evening.  Lake levels are currently falling but are expected to rise again from lunchtime today. It is expected that this Flood Alert will remain in force until at least the middle of the week. Rivers in the area may also show some response and start rising from mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any further flood warnings.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to expected rainfall throughout the morning, 27/8/24.  A band of heavy rain is expected to cross Cumbria throughout the morning, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area. This will be followed by a period of showers, clearing by this evening.  Lake levels are currently falling but are expected to rise again from lunchtime today. It is expected that this Flood Alert will remain in force until at least the middle of the week. Rivers in the area may also show some response and start rising from mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any further flood warnings.

Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
Due to a band of heavy rain crossing Cumbria this morning 27/08/24, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area, we are beginning to see river levels starting to rise and this is likely to continue until early hours of tomorrow morning 28/08/24. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings. This current band of rain will be followed by a period of showers, clearing overnight. We will then hopefully see a drier few days.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston.

We are closely monitoring the situation and closely monitoring the situation.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ehen, Rive Calder, River Irt, River Esk

items.message:
A band of heavy rain is expected to cross Cumbria throughout this morning, Tuesday 27/08/2024, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area. This will be followed by a period of showers, clearing by this evening. Rivers in the area are expected to show some response and start rising from mid morning. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Ehen, Calder, Irt and Esk and other watercourses, from Harrington to Annaside including low lying areas around Whitehaven, Cleator Moor, Egremont, Gosforth, Eskdale and Bootle.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message:
Due to a band of heavy rain crossing Cumbria this morning 27/08/24, bringing up to approx. 65mm rain in the upland area, we are beginning to see river levels start rising and this is likely to continue until early hours of tomorrow morning 28/08/24. We are not currently expecting to issue any flood warnings.  This current band of rain will be followed by period of showers, clearing overnight.  We will then hopefully see a drier few days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot.

We are closely monitoring the situation and closely monitoring the situation.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 28/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
